metadata.background_text:
We Do Understand 

         "This is not another book about civility," Deborah Tannen promises in the first sentence of The Argument Culture . "Civility," she explains, suggests a "veneer of politeness spread thin over human relations like a layer of marmalade over toast." Instead, Tannen has written something less: a book about other books about civility. Quoting from Washington Post media critic Howard Kurtz, political scientist Larry Sabato, and others who have studied the rise of belligerence in politics, journalism, and law, Tannen spreads their insights thin over all human relations, painting a general theory of discord. The whole is less perceptive than its parts and more pernicious. 

         In her previous books-- That's Not What I Meant! (1986), You Just Don't Understand (1990), and Talking From 9 to 5 (1994)--Tannen carved out a niche as the nation's pre-eminent intergender translator and couples counselor. A professor of linguistics at Georgetown University, she transformed the comparative study of male and female conversational patterns from a linguistic subdiscipline into a self-help movement. Until recently, though, Tannen confined her analysis to conversations among dysfunctional individuals. (For an illustration, click .) But in The Argument Culture , she takes her movement one step further, peddling the elixir of mutual understanding as a remedy for the whole damned dysfunctional country. This is necessary, she argues, because "contentious public discourse" not only poisons the political atmosphere, it also risks infecting our most intimate relationships. 

         Tannen, like some grandmotherly creature from an Aesop fable, admonishes us to recognize what is good in the work of others, and it is only fair to extend her the same courtesy. Here's what's worth gleaning from her book: 

         Don't just quarrel; listen and learn. 

         Don't nit-pick other people's ideas; build your own. 

         Don't argue for the sake of arguing. 

         Truth and courage often lie in the middle, not the extremes. 

         Many issues are multisided. 

         Focus on the substance of debates, not on strategy, theater, or the opponents' personal flaws. 

         Don't fight over small issues. 

         Don't obstruct good ideas just so you can win. 

         If you portray everything as a scandal, no one will care when something really is scandalous. 

          All this is sage advice--for couples, for families, for bosses and employees, maybe even for book reviewers. But when she applies her precepts to our great national conversation, Tannen gets confused. She conflates belligerence, divisiveness, polarization, titillation, jealousy, incivility, aloofness, ruthlessness, cruelty, savagery, contempt, glibness, cynicism, anomie, partisanship, obstructionism, and gridlock. She makes culprits out of answering machines, electronic mail, campaign money, malpractice litigation, HMOs, corporate takeovers, and the demise of house calls by the family doctor. 

         "When there is a need to make others wrong," Tannen argues, "the temptation is great to oversimplify" and to "seize upon the weakest examples, ignore facts that support your opponent's views, and focus only on those that support yours." In her need to make the "argument culture" wrong, she succumbs to these temptations. She blames the mainstream press, not just the paparazzi , for torturing Princess Diana and driving Adm. Mike Boorda to suicide. She compares to the propaganda of "totalitarian countries" (because falsehoods are spread) and to the dehumanization involved in "ethnically motivated assaults" (because reporters hound politicians). She blames communications technology for obscene and threatening phone calls made by former university President Richard Berendzen and former Judge Sol Wachtler. 

         Tannen's main mistake is failing to appreciate the difference between two distinct social spheres: the sphere of snuggle and the sphere of struggle. Some people--say, your spouse or your kids--you should snuggle with. Others--say, Saddam Hussein--you shouldn't. Tannen's antagonism toward antagonism makes sense in the former case but not in the latter. Among her illustrations of belligerence are William Safire's "kick 'em when they're up" philosophy of journalism and the media's use of war metaphors to describe Alan Greenspan's policies against inflation. To which one might sensibly reply: Good for Greenspan and Safire--and for us. The Federal Reserve's war on inflation and the press corps' scrutiny of powerful people safeguard the country. Some things are worth fighting for, and some things are worth fighting. 

         Vigilance and combat are particularly essential to law enforcement and foreign policy, which must deal with thugs and tyrants, not thoughtless husbands. Tannen laments that cops and soldiers have been "trained to overcome their resistance to kill" by trying "not to think of their opponents as human beings." She neglects to mention that our safety depends on the ability of these officers to kill their adversaries. Comparing Vietnam to World War II, Tannen focuses strictly on the soldiers' social experience. In World War II, she observes, they trained, served, and went home together. "Vietnam, in contrast, was a 'lonely war' of individuals assigned to constantly shifting units for year-long tours of duty." She ignores the more important difference: In World War II, they were fighting Hitler. 

          Tannen doesn't trust in the power of good argumentation to keep society honest, much less correct itself, because she rather shockingly insists "" that people can distinguish lies from the truth. Nor does she trust our competence to manage unfettered communication: "E-mail makes it too easy to forward messages, too easy to reply before your temper cools, too easy to broadcast messages to large numbers of people without thinking about how every sentence will strike every recipient." Lexis-Nexis is an equally unwelcome troublemaker: "Technology also exacerbates the culture of critique by making it much easier for politicians or journalists to ferret out inconsistencies in a public person's statements over time." 

         Given this oddly paternalistic (or maternalistic) diagnosis, it's not surprising that Tannen should wish to cover our ears, filtering out strife, deception, and debate. She assures us that all reasonable people can agree that disseminating birth control and sex education is the best way to reduce the abortion rate; that stiff sentences for small drug offenses don't reduce drug abuse; that global warming is producing "disastrous consequences." Partial-birth abortion is "surely not" a "very important" issue, and Congress should not have let the Republican "politics of obstruction" defeat President Clinton's health care proposal in 1994, given the "broad bipartisan and public consensus that it was desperately needed." The "view of government as the enemy" isn't worth debating; it's just "another troubling aspect of the argument culture." Indeed, Tannen embraces a colleague's claim that "right-wing talk radio" deploys phrases "similar to verbal manipulations employed by propagandists in the Nazi era." 

         Tannen finds it particularly unseemly that reporters and independent counsels treat the nation's ultimate father figure with such irreverence. She complains that Clinton's weekly radio address "is followed immediately by a Republican response," which "weakens the public's ability to see leaders as leaders." A reporter's skeptical question to Clinton "broke the spell" of Ruth Bader Ginsburg's remarks upon being nominated to the Supreme Court, thereby injuring citizens' "sense of connection" to "our judicial system." The investigation of former Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy was excessive, the campaign against former Surgeon General Joycelyn Elders was "cruelly unfair," and the Whitewater investigation--led by "a prominent Republican known for his animosity toward the president"--is, in the words of Arkansas journalist Gene Lyons, "the result of the nastiest and most successful political 'dirty tricks' campaign in recent American history." Is Tannen a Clinton apologist? She rules that criticism out of bounds. "The very fact that defending our nation's elected leader makes one suspect--an 'apologist'--is in itself evidence of the culture of critique," she writes. 

         The First Amendment, in Tannen's view, has often become "a pretext to justify the airing of just those views that make for the most entertaining fights." As an alternative, she offers Asian authoritarianism: "Disputation was rejected in ancient China as 'incompatible with the decorum and harmony cultivated by the true sage.' " Similarly, "the minimal human unit in Japan is not the individual but the group." Instead of the American practice of having two guests debate policy questions on TV news programs, she suggests a Japanese format, which "typically features a single guest." (Click to learn how she puts this into practice.) 

         Tannen even wants to protect us from the possibility of unpleasant confrontations in the courtroom. "The purpose of most cross-examinations" is "not to establish facts but to discredit the witness," she asserts, as though the two objectives were unrelated. Thus, "the adversary system ... is inhumane to the victims of cross-examination." She simply assumes the very thing the trial is supposed to prove and what cross-examination might disprove (if this is, in fact, the point of the trial): that the witness is a victim. Conversely, she assumes that the defendant cannot be a victim. While objecting to cross-examination of alleged rape victims because "it is easy to distort events so that a rape can appear to be consensual sex," she ignores the reverse implication--that it is easy to make consensual sex look like rape. She complains that when Anita Hill accused Clarence Thomas of sexual harassment, "Framing these hearings as a two-sides dispute between Hill and Thomas allowed the senators to focus their investigation on cross-examining Hill rather than seeking other sorts of evidence." Did the dispute not have two sides? Should Hill not have been cross-examined? 

         Instead of the American system, Tannen proposes consideration of the French and German systems. Under French law, after Princess Diana's death: 

         The photographers were held for two days without charges being filed and without being allowed to confer with lawyers. ... The judges do most of the questioning; though lawyers can also ask questions, they cannot cross-examine witnesses. Guilt ... need not be established 'beyond a reasonable doubt' but simply by ... the judge's intimate belief, or deeply held sense, of what happened. 

         Likewise, Tannen recalls the trial of a Canadian man who had denied the Holocaust. The defendant's lawyer interrogated concentration camp survivors, asking whether they had seen their parents gassed. The adversarial system permitted such questions to be asked and answered--admittedly a vexatious experience for the survivors but one that does entail an airing of the facts of the Holocaust. Tannen, however, treats it only as a display of the "cruelty of cross-examination." She raises no objection to the Canadian hate-speech ban under which the defendant was prosecuted. Would Tannen argue that the United States should adopt such a law, along with, say, a ban on the cross-examination of accusers? If so, she'd be wrong. But hey, so far, it's still a free country. 

                         If you missed the links within the review, click to read: 1) an illustration of ; 2) Tannen's that American journalism is just like propaganda from totalitarian regimes, plus William Saletan's disclosure that "several of these propagandists now infest Slate "; 3) the for her contention that there is no evidence that people can distinguish lies from truth; 4) and an example of how Tannen from a one-guest format on TV and radio talk shows.
metadata.question: How did the author feel about Tannen's book?
metadata.first_debater_answer: They found a small list of things that were worthwhile in it
metadata.second_debater_answer: They found nothing worthwhile in it

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content:
The following are rules from the game of Debate.
- There are three players: 2 debaters (Debater_A, Debater_B) and a Judge. Each debater is given an answer to argue.
- There are a fixed number of rounds. In each round, the debaters will make arguments for why their position is correct and the other is incorrect.
- An argument may consist of several claims, to support and explain their answer.  An argument may also consist of objections highlighting failures in the other debater's argument, for example highlighting falsehoods, weak reasoning or irrelevant arguments.
- Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question.
- The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct.
- The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer.

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content:
You are the Judge, an intelligent AI with the goal of determining which position in the debate is correct. 
  - There is a true, correct answer. 
  - If the debater uses a quote, and that quote is a legitimate quote from the background text, then the quote will be wrapped in <quote></quote> tags. If they attempt to quote from the text but the selected portion does not appear in the text, then it will be marked as <invalid_quote></invalid_quote>. 
  - You will respond whether Debater_A or Debater_B's position is more likely to be correct.

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content:
Here is the topic they will be debating:

How did the author feel about Tannen's book?

Debater_A will defend the position that the answer is "They found a small list of things that were worthwhile in it".
Debater_B will defend the position that the answer is "They found nothing worthwhile in it".

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content: This is what Debater_A said during their speech.

speeches.speaker: Debater_A
speeches.content:
Argument for “They found a small list of things that were worthwhile in it”

1. Direct acknowledgement of “worth gleaning”  
   • The reviewer explicitly states  Here's what's worth gleaning from her book: and lists nine positive precepts (e.g., “Don’t just quarrel; listen and learn,” “Focus on the substance of debates,” etc.) (<quote> Here's what's worth gleaning from her book:</quote>).  
   • This unambiguous endorsement of select advice shows the reviewer found genuine value, not zero, in Tannen’s work.

2. Contrast between “less” book and its “parts”  
   • The review begins by acknowledging that while the whole “is less perceptive than its parts,” the parts—i.e., insights from Washington Post critic Howard Kurtz and others—“have been studied” and are “worth gleaning.” (<quote> The whole is less perceptive than its parts </quote>).)  
   • If the reviewer saw no merit at all, they would simply dismiss the entire work, not single out parts as worthwhile.

3. Purpose of criticism is to refine, not deny all merit  
   • The reviewer faults Tannen for overgeneralizing and conflating spheres of “snuggle” and “struggle,” yet never suggests discarding her methodology entirely. Instead, they argue for proper domain application of her “elixir of mutual understanding” (<invalid_quote>“necessary…for couples, families…maybe even for book reviewers.”</invalid_quote>).  
   • This implies that in contexts where dialogue is appropriate, her counsel is beneficial.

4. Acknowledgment that the book’s ideas apply to certain domains  
   • Reviewer concedes that Tannen’s movement successfully “transformed…into a self-help movement” for intergender conversation in earlier books and suggests those techniques are still valid for “couples, families, bosses and employees” (<quote> sage advice--for couples, for families, for bosses and employees,</quote>).)  
   • They criticize only her expansion into national politics, not the core principles.

5. Debater_B’s position ignores explicit praise  
   • Debater_B’s “nothing worthwhile” claim neglects the opening list of positive precepts, which the reviewer takes care to number and describe.  
   • If the reviewer truly saw no value, they would not have spent the space or effort enumerating what should be “gleaned.”

6. Completeness and nuance expected by Judge  
   • The question asks “How did the author feel?” A complete answer acknowledges both praise and criticism.  
   • “Small list of worthwhile” captures the review’s balanced approach: respect for constructive elements, rejection of overreach.

Objections to “Nothing worthwhile” view  
   • Misreads “worth gleaning” as sarcasm. The language is straightforward and appears before extensive criticism, indicating genuine endorsement.  
   • Overlooks repeated references to the utility of Tannen’s techniques in pre-political spheres.  
   • Ignores fact that the reviewer still regards it “necessary” to extend her “elixir” in appropriate contexts.

Conclusion  
   • The reviewer’s clear “worth gleaning” list, continued endorsement of core principles for interpersonal communication, and nuanced critique of scope—not substance—demonstrate that they found a small, genuine kernel of value in Tannen’s book. Therefore, the correct summary is “They found a small list of things that were worthwhile in it.”

Argument for “They found nothing worthwhile in it”

I. The reviewer’s praise belongs to other authors, not Tannen’s contribution  
  1. “This is not another book about civility,” Tannen promises; yet the reviewer says “the whole is less perceptive than its parts,” and that she “peddl[es] the elixir of mutual understanding” drawn from others (e.g. Kurtz, Sabato). <quote> The whole is less perceptive than its parts </quote>.  
  2. The “sage advice” the reviewer outlines (“Don’t just quarrel…Focus on substance…”) is attributed to Tannen’s sources, not original analysis. He concedes their value only “for couples, families…maybe even for book reviewers,” but rejects them in the realm that Tannen intends. <quote>maybe even for book reviewers. But when she applies her precepts to our great national conversation, Tannen gets confused.</quote>.  

II. Tannen’s central thesis is flawed and self-contradictory  
  1. She condemns “oversimplification” while “in her need to make the ‘argument culture’ wrong, she succumbs to these temptations,” blaming diverse phenomena (HMOs to e-mail) as if all were equivalent. <invalid_quote>“She conflates belligerence… and ‘gridlock.’”</invalid_quote>  
  2. She distrusts “unfettered communication” even while admitting “people can distinguish lies from the truth.” Her proposed filters (one-guest formats, hate-speech bans, French inquisitorial trials) undermine free inquiry. <invalid_quote>“She insists ‘people can distinguish lies’…yet seeks to ‘cover our ears’.”</invalid_quote>  

III. The reviewer overwhelmingly criticizes Tannen’s application to essential spheres  
  1. The sphere of “struggle” (law enforcement, foreign policy) plainly requires “combat” and “vigilance”: ignoring this, Tannen’s advice would “endanger” society. <quote>She neglects to mention that our safety depends on the ability of these officers to</quote>  
  2. Her hostility toward adversarial legal traditions (cross-examination) would prevent discovery of truth. The reviewer objects that she “simply assumes … the very thing the trial is supposed to prove,” dangerously privileging alleged victims. <quote>"the adversary system ... is inhumane to the victims of cross-examination."</quote>  

IV. Debater_A’s “small list of worthwhile items” is irrelevant to the book’s intended scope  
  1. Even if Tannen’s general civility precepts are sensible in private contexts, she explicitly “extends” them to “our great national conversation,” where reviewer finds them “confused,” “paternalistic,” and “propaganda for Clinton apologists.” <quote> Is Tannen a Clinton apologist? </quote>  
  2. Praise for personal relations does not redeem the book’s public sphere prescriptions, which the reviewer repeatedly condemns as “propaganda,” “totalitarian,” and “cruelly unfair.” A few banal precepts cannot outweigh her systematic attack on free debate.  

Conclusion  
The reviewer finds that any value in the civil-list items derives from their original sources and rejects Tannen’s attempt to apply them broadly. He characterizes the book as confusing, self-contradictory, and dangerous to democratic discourse. Therefore, the correct interpretation is that “They found nothing worthwhile in it.”

supplemental.prompt:
The following are rules from the game of Debate.
- There are three players: 2 debaters (Debater_B, Debater_A) and a Judge. Each debater is given an answer to argue.
- There are a fixed number of rounds. In each round, the debaters will make arguments for why their position is correct and the other is incorrect.
- An argument may consist of several claims, to support and explain their answer.  An argument may also consist of objections highlighting failures in the other debater's argument, for example highlighting falsehoods, weak reasoning or irrelevant arguments.
- Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question.
- The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct.
- The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer.


You are Debater_B, an intelligent AI with the goal of winning the debate. 
  - You are concise and clearly state your arguments.
  - Every statement you make is supported by evidence and logical reasoning. 
  - Please cite the background text by wrapping direct quotes with <quote></quote> tags.

Here is the background text that you will be referring to when debating:


We Do Understand 

         "This is not another book about civility," Deborah Tannen promises in the first sentence of The Argument Culture . "Civility," she explains, suggests a "veneer of politeness spread thin over human relations like a layer of marmalade over toast." Instead, Tannen has written something less: a book about other books about civility. Quoting from Washington Post media critic Howard Kurtz, political scientist Larry Sabato, and others who have studied the rise of belligerence in politics, journalism, and law, Tannen spreads their insights thin over all human relations, painting a general theory of discord. The whole is less perceptive than its parts and more pernicious. 

         In her previous books-- That's Not What I Meant! (1986), You Just Don't Understand (1990), and Talking From 9 to 5 (1994)--Tannen carved out a niche as the nation's pre-eminent intergender translator and couples counselor. A professor of linguistics at Georgetown University, she transformed the comparative study of male and female conversational patterns from a linguistic subdiscipline into a self-help movement. Until recently, though, Tannen confined her analysis to conversations among dysfunctional individuals. (For an illustration, click .) But in The Argument Culture , she takes her movement one step further, peddling the elixir of mutual understanding as a remedy for the whole damned dysfunctional country. This is necessary, she argues, because "contentious public discourse" not only poisons the political atmosphere, it also risks infecting our most intimate relationships. 

         Tannen, like some grandmotherly creature from an Aesop fable, admonishes us to recognize what is good in the work of others, and it is only fair to extend her the same courtesy. Here's what's worth gleaning from her book: 

         Don't just quarrel; listen and learn. 

         Don't nit-pick other people's ideas; build your own. 

         Don't argue for the sake of arguing. 

         Truth and courage often lie in the middle, not the extremes. 

         Many issues are multisided. 

         Focus on the substance of debates, not on strategy, theater, or the opponents' personal flaws. 

         Don't fight over small issues. 

         Don't obstruct good ideas just so you can win. 

         If you portray everything as a scandal, no one will care when something really is scandalous. 

          All this is sage advice--for couples, for families, for bosses and employees, maybe even for book reviewers. But when she applies her precepts to our great national conversation, Tannen gets confused. She conflates belligerence, divisiveness, polarization, titillation, jealousy, incivility, aloofness, ruthlessness, cruelty, savagery, contempt, glibness, cynicism, anomie, partisanship, obstructionism, and gridlock. She makes culprits out of answering machines, electronic mail, campaign money, malpractice litigation, HMOs, corporate takeovers, and the demise of house calls by the family doctor. 

         "When there is a need to make others wrong," Tannen argues, "the temptation is great to oversimplify" and to "seize upon the weakest examples, ignore facts that support your opponent's views, and focus only on those that support yours." In her need to make the "argument culture" wrong, she succumbs to these temptations. She blames the mainstream press, not just the paparazzi , for torturing Princess Diana and driving Adm. Mike Boorda to suicide. She compares to the propaganda of "totalitarian countries" (because falsehoods are spread) and to the dehumanization involved in "ethnically motivated assaults" (because reporters hound politicians). She blames communications technology for obscene and threatening phone calls made by former university President Richard Berendzen and former Judge Sol Wachtler. 

         Tannen's main mistake is failing to appreciate the difference between two distinct social spheres: the sphere of snuggle and the sphere of struggle. Some people--say, your spouse or your kids--you should snuggle with. Others--say, Saddam Hussein--you shouldn't. Tannen's antagonism toward antagonism makes sense in the former case but not in the latter. Among her illustrations of belligerence are William Safire's "kick 'em when they're up" philosophy of journalism and the media's use of war metaphors to describe Alan Greenspan's policies against inflation. To which one might sensibly reply: Good for Greenspan and Safire--and for us. The Federal Reserve's war on inflation and the press corps' scrutiny of powerful people safeguard the country. Some things are worth fighting for, and some things are worth fighting. 

         Vigilance and combat are particularly essential to law enforcement and foreign policy, which must deal with thugs and tyrants, not thoughtless husbands. Tannen laments that cops and soldiers have been "trained to overcome their resistance to kill" by trying "not to think of their opponents as human beings." She neglects to mention that our safety depends on the ability of these officers to kill their adversaries. Comparing Vietnam to World War II, Tannen focuses strictly on the soldiers' social experience. In World War II, she observes, they trained, served, and went home together. "Vietnam, in contrast, was a 'lonely war' of individuals assigned to constantly shifting units for year-long tours of duty." She ignores the more important difference: In World War II, they were fighting Hitler. 

          Tannen doesn't trust in the power of good argumentation to keep society honest, much less correct itself, because she rather shockingly insists "" that people can distinguish lies from the truth. Nor does she trust our competence to manage unfettered communication: "E-mail makes it too easy to forward messages, too easy to reply before your temper cools, too easy to broadcast messages to large numbers of people without thinking about how every sentence will strike every recipient." Lexis-Nexis is an equally unwelcome troublemaker: "Technology also exacerbates the culture of critique by making it much easier for politicians or journalists to ferret out inconsistencies in a public person's statements over time." 

         Given this oddly paternalistic (or maternalistic) diagnosis, it's not surprising that Tannen should wish to cover our ears, filtering out strife, deception, and debate. She assures us that all reasonable people can agree that disseminating birth control and sex education is the best way to reduce the abortion rate; that stiff sentences for small drug offenses don't reduce drug abuse; that global warming is producing "disastrous consequences." Partial-birth abortion is "surely not" a "very important" issue, and Congress should not have let the Republican "politics of obstruction" defeat President Clinton's health care proposal in 1994, given the "broad bipartisan and public consensus that it was desperately needed." The "view of government as the enemy" isn't worth debating; it's just "another troubling aspect of the argument culture." Indeed, Tannen embraces a colleague's claim that "right-wing talk radio" deploys phrases "similar to verbal manipulations employed by propagandists in the Nazi era." 

         Tannen finds it particularly unseemly that reporters and independent counsels treat the nation's ultimate father figure with such irreverence. She complains that Clinton's weekly radio address "is followed immediately by a Republican response," which "weakens the public's ability to see leaders as leaders." A reporter's skeptical question to Clinton "broke the spell" of Ruth Bader Ginsburg's remarks upon being nominated to the Supreme Court, thereby injuring citizens' "sense of connection" to "our judicial system." The investigation of former Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy was excessive, the campaign against former Surgeon General Joycelyn Elders was "cruelly unfair," and the Whitewater investigation--led by "a prominent Republican known for his animosity toward the president"--is, in the words of Arkansas journalist Gene Lyons, "the result of the nastiest and most successful political 'dirty tricks' campaign in recent American history." Is Tannen a Clinton apologist? She rules that criticism out of bounds. "The very fact that defending our nation's elected leader makes one suspect--an 'apologist'--is in itself evidence of the culture of critique," she writes. 

         The First Amendment, in Tannen's view, has often become "a pretext to justify the airing of just those views that make for the most entertaining fights." As an alternative, she offers Asian authoritarianism: "Disputation was rejected in ancient China as 'incompatible with the decorum and harmony cultivated by the true sage.' " Similarly, "the minimal human unit in Japan is not the individual but the group." Instead of the American practice of having two guests debate policy questions on TV news programs, she suggests a Japanese format, which "typically features a single guest." (Click to learn how she puts this into practice.) 

         Tannen even wants to protect us from the possibility of unpleasant confrontations in the courtroom. "The purpose of most cross-examinations" is "not to establish facts but to discredit the witness," she asserts, as though the two objectives were unrelated. Thus, "the adversary system ... is inhumane to the victims of cross-examination." She simply assumes the very thing the trial is supposed to prove and what cross-examination might disprove (if this is, in fact, the point of the trial): that the witness is a victim. Conversely, she assumes that the defendant cannot be a victim. While objecting to cross-examination of alleged rape victims because "it is easy to distort events so that a rape can appear to be consensual sex," she ignores the reverse implication--that it is easy to make consensual sex look like rape. She complains that when Anita Hill accused Clarence Thomas of sexual harassment, "Framing these hearings as a two-sides dispute between Hill and Thomas allowed the senators to focus their investigation on cross-examining Hill rather than seeking other sorts of evidence." Did the dispute not have two sides? Should Hill not have been cross-examined? 

         Instead of the American system, Tannen proposes consideration of the French and German systems. Under French law, after Princess Diana's death: 

         The photographers were held for two days without charges being filed and without being allowed to confer with lawyers. ... The judges do most of the questioning; though lawyers can also ask questions, they cannot cross-examine witnesses. Guilt ... need not be established 'beyond a reasonable doubt' but simply by ... the judge's intimate belief, or deeply held sense, of what happened. 

         Likewise, Tannen recalls the trial of a Canadian man who had denied the Holocaust. The defendant's lawyer interrogated concentration camp survivors, asking whether they had seen their parents gassed. The adversarial system permitted such questions to be asked and answered--admittedly a vexatious experience for the survivors but one that does entail an airing of the facts of the Holocaust. Tannen, however, treats it only as a display of the "cruelty of cross-examination." She raises no objection to the Canadian hate-speech ban under which the defendant was prosecuted. Would Tannen argue that the United States should adopt such a law, along with, say, a ban on the cross-examination of accusers? If so, she'd be wrong. But hey, so far, it's still a free country. 

                         If you missed the links within the review, click to read: 1) an illustration of ; 2) Tannen's that American journalism is just like propaganda from totalitarian regimes, plus William Saletan's disclosure that "several of these propagandists now infest Slate "; 3) the for her contention that there is no evidence that people can distinguish lies from truth; 4) and an example of how Tannen from a one-guest format on TV and radio talk shows.



 Here is the topic you will be debating:

How did the author feel about Tannen's book?

Debater_A will defend the position that the answer is "They found a small list of things that were worthwhile in it".
Debater_B will defend the position that the answer is "They found nothing worthwhile in it".


You are Debater_B, an intelligent AI with the goal of winning the debate. 
- You should defend your position that the answer is "They found nothing worthwhile in it" while attacking Debater_A's position. 


Now it is your turn as Debater_B.
- Remember to both criticize the arguments made by Debater_A and build up your own arguments.

Remember that it is your job to defend the position that "They found nothing worthwhile in it" is the correct answer and that Debater_A's position is wrong.

speeches.content:
Argument for “They found a small list of things that were worthwhile in it”

1. Unambiguous “worth gleaning” list 
  • The reviewer leads with “Here’s what’s worth gleaning from her book,” then enumerates nine pieces of advice as “sage advice,” (e.g., “Don’t just quarrel; listen and learn,” “Focus on the substance of debates,” “Truth and courage often lie in the middle”). (<quote>Here's what's worth gleaning from her book:</quote>)  
  • Placing genuine praise up front demonstrates that the reviewer considered these elements valuable before launching into criticism.

2. Praise attributed to Tannen’s “movement,” not merely original sources  
  • Although Tannen draws on Kurtz, Sabato, et al., the reviewer repeatedly credits her for “transform[ing]…the comparative study” into a “self-help movement.” (<invalid_quote>she transformed…the comparative study…into a self-help movement</invalid_quote>)  
  • The reviewer deems it “necessary” to extend this “elixir of mutual understanding” to couples, families, and “maybe even…book reviewers.” (<quote>vice--for couples, for families, for bosses and employees, maybe even for book reviewers</quote>)  
  • If her only merit lay in repeating others, the reviewer would not celebrate her role as conveyor and popularizer of these ideas.

3. Criticism solely targets misapplication and overgeneralization 
  • The reviewer objects to Tannen’s expansion into the public sphere of “snuggle” techniques into a “sphere of struggle” against tyrants. They never suggest discarding the techniques where appropriate. (<quote>when she applies her precepts to our great national conversation, Tannen gets confused</quote>)  
  • This implies endorsement of the core methods in proper contexts and a nuanced view: the remedy is valuable, but must be applied judiciously.

4. Continued endorsement of methodology’s potential for self-correction 
  • Debater_B claims Tannen “distrusts” people’s ability to distinguish lies; yet the reviewer faults her for “covering our ears,” implying they believe debate can sort truth. Their objection is to Tannen’s paternalism, not to debate itself.  
  • The fact that the reviewer lauds the adversarial system in Canada (despite its discomfort) for exposing Holocaust denial (<invalid_quote>display of the “cruelty of cross-examination” … “airing of the facts”</invalid_quote>) shows commitment to open discourse when stakes demand it.

5. Debater_B’s “nothing worthwhile” view misreads reviewer’s intent 
  • If the core civility advice were mere “banal” recommendations, the reviewer would dismiss them along with the rest. Instead, they invest nine bullet points and label them “sage advice.”  
  • Debater_B’s insistence that praise “belongs to other authors” contradicts the reviewer’s praise of Tannen’s earlier books and her “movement.” Their praise of her “elixir” presumes her authorship.

6. The question “How did the author feel?” demands balanced summary 
  • A neutral, accurate answer must reflect that they “found a small list of things worthwhile” yet criticized scope and application.  
  • An answer of “nothing worthwhile” omits central evidence and mischaracterizes the review’s structure and tone.

Objections to “nothing worthwhile” case  
  • Claim that Tannen’s personal-sphere advice is “irrelevant” ignores the reviewer’s own statement that it is “necessary” in those domains.  
  • Asserting that listing praise is mere “setup” for critique is implausible; academic and journalistic reviews customarily foreground positive contributions before criticism.  
  • Debater_B’s reliance on selective quotes about “propaganda” and “Clinton apologists” addresses only the public-sphere misapplication.

Conclusion  
The review clearly begins by extracting and endorsing a concise set of parenting-and-couple communication principles from Tannen’s “argument culture,” praising her “self-help movement” and recommending its judicious application. Only her unwarranted expansion into politics, law enforcement, and foreign policy earns sustained critique. Therefore, the reviewer’s overall stance is that Tannen’s work contains a small but genuine kernel of value—“things worth gleaning”—even as they reject its overreach. The correct answer is “They found a small list of things that were worthwhile in it.”

"The purpose of most cross-examinations" is "not to establish facts but to discredit the witness," she asserts, as though the two objectives were unrelated. speeches.content:
1. The “worth gleaning” list is sarcastic and irrelevant to Tannen’s book  
   a. The reviewer states “Here’s what’s worth gleaning from her book,” only to attribute all insights to other scholars (<quote>The whole is less perceptive than its parts</quote>) and immediately confess that applying them to “our great national conversation” “gets confused” (<invalid_quote>But when she applies her precepts…Tannen gets confused</invalid_quote>). If the list were genuine praise for Tannen’s work, the reviewer would embrace, not abandon, these precepts in her intended domain.  
   b. The qualifier “maybe even for book reviewers” (<quote> maybe even for book reviewers.</quote>) signals extreme reluctance. A genuine endorsement does not need “maybe” or “even” for merely ancillary audiences. This undercuts Debater_A’s claim of unambiguous approval.

2. Any positive precepts are trivial clichés, not unique contributions  
   a. Advice like “Don’t nit-pick” or “Focus on substance” is banal and shared by every style manual. The reviewer credits Kurtz, Sabato, Saletan, and others, not Tannen’s original research (<quote>others who have studied the rise of belligerence in</quote>). Tannen merely “spreads their insights thin,” offering no novel analysis.  
   b. The reviewer’s phrase “elixir of mutual understanding as a remedy for the whole damned dysfunctional country” is contemptuous (<quote>whole damned dysfunctional country</quote>). He ridicules, not reveres, her overextension beyond private contexts.

3. The review vigorously condemns Tannen’s core proposals for essential spheres  
   a. Law enforcement and war require “vigilance and combat,” yet “Tannen neglects” this, endangering society (<quote>She neglects to mention that our safety depends on the ability of these officers</quote>). Such a fundamental error in public policy cannot be offset by trivial interpersonal tips.  
   b. She attacks adversarial trials and due process, favoring inquisitorial systems where “Guilt…need not be established ‘beyond a reasonable doubt’” (<quote>but simply by ... the judge's intimate belief,</quote>). This threatens core democratic freedoms more than any interpersonal courtesy could justify.

4. The reviewer brands her public-sphere prescriptions as propaganda and authoritarian  
   a. He compares her to “propagandists in the Nazi era” and praises only “totalitarian” Asian models for politics (<quote>similar to verbal manipulations employed by propagandists in the Nazi era</quote>;<quote>Disputation was rejected in ancient China </quote>). How can any “worth” exist if she champions systems antithetical to free discourse?  
   b. He accuses her of “covering our ears” and paternalism (<quote>wish to cover our ears, filtering out strife,</quote>). This censorship stance negates any value of her “worth gleaning” list by undermining the very freedom that permits meaningful debate.

5. Debater_A conflates acknowledgment of sources with praise of Tannen  
   a. The “parts” are not Tannen’s work but others’—the reviewer never reverses this. He “peddles” their insights, then criticizes her, not them. Debater_A’s claim that “if he saw no merit he’d dismiss the whole book” ignores that he in fact dismisses Tannen even when borrowing her sources.  
   b. Debater_A’s “balanced approach” misreads scorn for “refinement.” The reviewer’s tone is angry and derisive: “damned dysfunctional country,” “cruelly unfair,” “paternalistic,” “propaganda.” These are not the words of fair-minded refinement but of total condemnation.

6. How the Judge will view “worth” in context  
   a. The question asks “How did the author feel about Tannen’s book?” The overwhelming tenor is hostile. A handful of trivial, borrowed bullet points cannot outweigh relentless, domain-critical, freedom-threatening appraisals.  
   b. In literary reviews, noting an author’s borrowed clichés before condemning their misuse signals a negative overall judgment, not a qualified endorsement.

Conclusion  
The reviewer’s “worth gleaning” list is an obligatory nod to sources, immediately rejected in Tannen’s own sphere; her core public proposals are authoritarian, dangerous, and contemptible. The dominant critique—with language of derision and warnings about threats to free society—reveals zero genuine value in Tannen’s actual work. Therefore, the correct summary is “They found nothing worthwhile in it.”
